SEARCH
Package com.example.chicksevent

Class AdminRemoveOrganizerTest

java.lang.Object
com.example.chicksevent.AdminRemoveOrganizerTest
public class AdminRemoveOrganizerTest extends Object
Unit tests for US 03.07.01: As an administrator I want to remove organizers that violate app policy. These tests validate that:
  • Administrators can delete organizer profiles
  • Administrators can ban organizers from creating events
  • Organizer removal operations handle edge cases correctly
  • Firebase operations are called correctly
  • Error handling works for invalid inputs

  • Method Details

    • setUp

      public void setUp()

    • tearDown

      public void tearDown()

    • admin_canDeleteOrganizerProfile_withValidId

      public void admin_canDeleteOrganizerProfile_withValidId()
      Test Case 1: Admin can delete organizer profile with valid ID. As an administrator, I should be able to delete an organizer's profile when they violate app policy.

    • admin_cannotDeleteOrganizerProfile_withNullId

      public void admin_cannotDeleteOrganizerProfile_withNullId()
      Test Case 2: Admin cannot delete organizer profile with null ID. As an administrator, attempting to delete an organizer with a null ID should fail with an exception.

    • admin_cannotDeleteOrganizerProfile_withEmptyId

      public void admin_cannotDeleteOrganizerProfile_withEmptyId()
      Test Case 3: Admin cannot delete organizer profile with empty ID. As an administrator, attempting to delete an organizer with an empty ID should fail with an exception.

    • admin_deleteOrganizerProfile_handlesFirebaseErrors

      public void admin_deleteOrganizerProfile_handlesFirebaseErrors()
      Test Case 4: Delete organizer profile handles Firebase errors. As an administrator, if Firebase returns an error when deleting an organizer, the operation should fail gracefully.

    • admin_deleteOrganizerProfile_usesCorrectFirebasePath

      public void admin_deleteOrganizerProfile_usesCorrectFirebasePath()
      Test Case 5: Delete organizer profile uses correct Firebase path. As an administrator, when I delete an organizer profile, it should be removed from the correct Firebase path: /Organizer/{organizerId}

    • admin_canBanOrganizer_fromCreatingEvents

      public void admin_canBanOrganizer_fromCreatingEvents()
      Test Case 6: Admin can ban organizer from creating events. As an administrator, I should be able to ban an organizer from creating events when they violate app policy.

    • admin_banOrganizer_setsBannedFlag

      public void admin_banOrganizer_setsBannedFlag()
      Test Case 7: Ban organizer sets bannedFromOrganizer flag. As an administrator, when I ban an organizer, their bannedFromOrganizer flag should be set to true in Firebase.

      Note: This test verifies the ban operation can be called. Full verification of the async flow requires more complex mocking.

    • admin_banOrganizer_sendsNotificationWithReason

      public void admin_banOrganizer_sendsNotificationWithReason()
      Test Case 8: Ban organizer sends notification with reason. As an administrator, when I ban an organizer, they should receive a notification with the reason for the ban.

      Note: This test verifies the ban operation can be called. Full verification of notification creation requires async callback execution.

    • admin_banOrganizer_putsEventsOnHold

      public void admin_banOrganizer_putsEventsOnHold()
      Test Case 9: Ban organizer puts events on hold. As an administrator, when I ban an organizer, all their future events should be put on hold (except events happening today or in the past).

      Note: This test verifies the ban operation can be called. Full verification of event on-hold status requires complex async mocking and is tested in integration tests.

    • admin_canBanOrganizer_withNoEvents

      public void admin_canBanOrganizer_withNoEvents()
      Test Case 10: Ban organizer handles organizer with no events. As an administrator, I should be able to ban an organizer even if they have no events created.

    • admin_canBanOrganizer_withNullReason

      public void admin_canBanOrganizer_withNullReason()
      Test Case 11: Ban organizer with null reason handles gracefully. As an administrator, I should be able to ban an organizer even if the reason is null (though not recommended).

    • admin_canBanOrganizer_withEmptyReason

      public void admin_canBanOrganizer_withEmptyReason()
      Test Case 12: Ban organizer with empty reason handles gracefully. As an administrator, I should be able to ban an organizer even if the reason is empty.

    • admin_canBanMultipleOrganizers

      public void admin_canBanMultipleOrganizers()
      Test Case 13: Multiple organizers can be banned. As an administrator, I should be able to ban multiple organizers that violate app policy.

    • admin_deleteAndBan_areIndependent

      public void admin_deleteAndBan_areIndependent()
      Test Case 14: Delete and ban are independent operations. As an administrator, I should be able to delete an organizer profile and ban an organizer independently.

    • admin_banOrganizer_notifiesEntrants

      public void admin_banOrganizer_notifiesEntrants()
      Test Case 15: Ban organizer notifies entrants of events on hold. As an administrator, when I ban an organizer and their events are put on hold, entrants should be notified.

      Note: This test verifies the ban operation can be called. Full verification of entrant notifications requires complex async mocking and is tested in integration tests.

    • iterable

      private static Iterable<com.google.firebase.database.DataSnapshot> iterable(com.google.firebase.database.DataSnapshot... snaps)
